text:
EDITED:
I have to edit a HubSpot landing page and the footer is floating.
To make things very short for you, I have no idea how this footer was added, or how to edit it properly, and would appreciate if anyone could please spend a moment with me to help me figure this out.

If this is the wrong channel, I'm sorry, and I will move the message.
Did y’all nix the HubSpot CMS for Developers Certification? We’re onboarding a dev and there’ no option to get certified

look in the page editor sidebar and select content. then see if it show there. Otherwise, you’ll have to go up top in the page editor to “settings”. Scroll down and expand advanced and find the template the page is using and click something like “edit this template”

It’s on hold until they update the curriculum this summer. I couldn’t renew my cert, either. I’ve talked to someone over there about extending the certs we can’t renew yet, so it doesn’t look like we let them expire. but as for new ones, it’s not nixed but it’s in limbo.
:pray::skin-tone-2:
hey I am able to get data from  <https://api.hubapi.com/marketing-emails/v1/emails?hapikey=XXX>
but it is working in postman
I am trying to fetch it through js code on my wp site
so it is giving me cors policy error

Work is in progress. We know everyone’s eager to renew or get newly certified. We’re updating it because we want to ensure that the certification keeps up with best practices for CMS development. If you’ve previously passed it likely won’t feel significantly harder, especially if you’ve been using themes, and whatnot. It does however increase the development requirements a little bit to more prove out that someone is actually a developer.

Are module CSS files deferred automatically so if I have a module that is on the bottom of the page the CSS file does not affect the loading of the above the fold content? I keep trying to figure out best practices for CSS. My current understanding would be to put all above the fold affecting CSS in the header and then defer the rest of the CSS.
no more squirrel photo gallery? LOL

oh no, galleries with animals may still very much be involved. We need some entertainment when grading these things lol

cc: <@U3PKJ8EQL>
maybe this time i’ll use otters.
Not gonna lie... I'm working cats into the videos too this time around...

We do not automatically cause all modules to load their CSS asynchronously. We can’t know which modules are considered “critical” as in critical CSS. We can’t know how tall your module is on the page reliably - it can be changed by CSS, JS, images loading causing reflow, CSS/JS animations etc.

Additionally you should use the asynchronous css loading intelligently.

for example if you have a css file that will dictate the majority of your template layout. That SHOULD be render blocking. Otherwise you’re going to get a flash of reflowing happening meaning you’re basically just delaying a sudden significant CLS spike.
DO IT
we need the comic relief, too. lurning iz hard

Additionally while this is a well joked about term now “above the fold” is not standard. viewing a page on an iPad in portrait mode? cool you see 90% of the page. 90% of the page is above the fold to you.
viewing the page on a smart watch? that 300px height is above the fold to you.

That doesn’t mean you shouldn’t prioritize above the fold, it just means you need to have some human intuition as to what’s truly the most important thing to be loading.
Strange question: Just like there is a forwarding email address like [portalid]@forward.HubSpot.com, is there something that we can use to log an email on a specific HubSpot ticket record?

Do all Hubl request variables disable caching, e.g. `request.query_dict`? It doesn’t say that in the docs, but the answer to “will this variable change or be different every time someone loads this page?” is yes.

Specifically noted ones.

For example if you have a query parameter change something in a page that query parameter version of the page can be cached.

Interesting, so if the query parameter has infinite possibilities, like if we have someone’s name in a query parameter that prints out to the page, it would kind of defeat the purpose of caching then?
In a case like that, guessing it would probably be better to use javascript to grab that value so the page can cache just once? Makes me want to reevaluate how we’re using the hubl in a few areas.

So for example say you use a query parameter to filter some hubdb results thatd be cached.

If youre printing say an email address to the page. You probably want to use JavaScript to grab the parameter instead because dozens of folks are not going to all go to that page with the same email in the URL
Right… thanks for clarifying! I don’t know why but that’s something I hadn’t really considered previously.

I do also want to note since it sounds like you're printing data directly from a query param to the page. Regardless of if using hubl or js. Id encourage sanitizing the data. That way for example someone couldnt put an html script tag in the query parameter and have you just print it to the page.
Righto! I believe HS has some sort of safeguard in place against that too, I think I remember trying to test our site for injection and it didn’t accept the script in the url
